awd_titl_txt: Collaborative proposal: Developing a battery of methods for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of silver and gold nanomaterials in human cells
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Ioana Pavel Sizemore/Adam de la Zerda
Proposal Number:  1438340/1434465
Institution: Wright State University/Stanford University 
Title: Collaborative proposal: Developing a battery of methods for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of silver and gold nanomaterials in human cells 

The extensive use of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) in consumer products and industry and the use of many kinds of NPs in healthcare as diagnostic and therapeutic tools require an understanding of their potential toxicities. However, as observed by the National Nanotechnology Initiative, there are only a limited number of techniques that could expand our understanding of the mechanisms by which nanomaterials influence cell behavior. The main scientific goal of this project is to fill these knowledge gaps by developing a battery of tools for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of environmentally representative AgNPs and biomedically relevant gold nanorods (AuNRs) in human cells. Key parameters, which will be considered in order to test the efficiency and practicality of the proposed methods, will include nanomaterial shape, surface charge, dose, and exposure time. The methods that are to be developed will be captured and shared through Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs). In addition, the knowledge gained from the proposed research will be used in setting up new course modules and will be disseminated into the broader community, e.g., through interactions with a local museum and development of two hour hands-on laboratory modules for over 100 K-6 through K-9 students. 

A battery of interdisciplinary methods (ICP-OES/TFF, Raman-SERS/MatLab codes, and electron microscopy /bioassays) will be used for the study of the trafficking mechanisms and transformations of environmentally representative silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) and biomedically relevant gold nanoparticles (AuNRs) in human cells. Key parameters that will be considered to test the efficiency and practicality of the proposed methods will include nanomaterial shape, surface charge, dose, and exposure time. To accomplish their goals, The PIs propose two specific aims. In Aim1, the PIs will characterize the physico-chemical properties of NPs, according to the U.S. EPA standards, before cellular exposure and then at various benchmark times during cellular trafficking. In Aim 2, using their suite of tools, the investigators will study the trafficking mechanisms of AgNPs and AuNRs in human cells as a function of nanomaterial shape, surface charge, dose, and exposure time.

por.por_cntn:
Cancer begins in the body as a few, and then a small population, of abnormal cells. While powerful molecular imaging tools exist for imaging hundreds of millions of cells (MRI) and tens of cells (various types of microscopes), it is the entire continuum in between that is of most interest in the clinic, where cancer is treated. Cancer resection is a pressing example of such a scenario, when it is crucial to analyze 100% of cancer cells, but the tools needed for single-cell in vivo imaging are still lacking.

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is an optical imaging technique that performs 3-dimensional, volumetric imaging in real-time, allowing one to see hundreds of millions of cells with nearly single cell resolution. But even in an OCT image, how can a doctor tell which cells are cancer and which are normal? There needs to a molecularly-targeted contrast agent, that binds only to cancer cells, and instantly reveals where they are in the image. This is one of the research foci in the de la Zerda lab, to enable molecular imaging at the scale of hundreds of millions of cells.

While there is a large and ever-growing number of OCT labs in the world, very few have attempted to image molecular contrast agents, and there are many challenges on this path. Our lab has made substantial progress towards this goal in the past 4 years. We began our journey with gold nanorods (GNRs), which are tiny nanoscale particles shaped like rods. They have the benefits of reflecting large amounts of light, making them easy to image, and being biologically safe to introduce into living organisms. We realized that we could enhance these reflecting properties further by using larger-than- usual GNRs (LGNRs), ~100 x 30 nm, which can exhibit 32-folder higher signal than GNRs (Figure 1). Both GNRs and LGNRs have another highly desirable property, which is that the wavelength of light they reflect can be controlled by fine-tuning the chemistry used to produce the nanorods.

With the LGNRs in hand, we developed the MOZART molecular imaging platform in 2016, which combines OCT imaging with custom signal processing techniques to “lock on” to the unique color of light reflected by a particular type of LGNR (Figure 2). Our signal processing technique also allows us to distinguish between the different LGNRs scattering different colors, and we simultaneously imaged two different LGNRs in a live mouse. This technology has enabled various projects, such as 1) visualizing lymphatic vessel flow 2) imaging molecularly-targeted protein biomarkers on the surface of lymphatic vessels in live mice 3) imaging of LGNR-labeled white-blood-cells that are re-administered into a mouse retina. We realized the enormous potential of this technology applied to imaging immune cells. Particularly, the MOZART platform could allow us to track the spatial-temporal behavior of immune and cancer cells in the tumors of living animals, as they respond to cancer-treating drugs.

However, we were aware that there was a significant obstacle towards this goal, one that is inherent to the physics of how OCT works. Because OCT uses coherent light, in which the light waves are perfectly aligned, the images it produces suffer from speckle noise, which results from wave-like interference that occurs between small particles being imaged. Speckle noise can severely compromise the effective resolution of an image, making it impossible to find small objects such as individual cells, against a speckled background. We developed an optical device specifically to address this issue, which, in the context of OCT, we dubbed Speckle-Modulating OCT (SM-OCT) (Figure 3). With SM-OCT, we could average out speckle noise in our image, revealing underlying biological structure that was hidden. Excitingly, we were able to visualize some detailed anatomical structures in living tissue with clarity that was unprecedented for an OCT with similar specifications.

Finally, in 2017, the SM-OCT technique, in conjunction with our LGNR imaging platform, MOZART, allowed us to capture the dynamics of (Figure 4) immune cells in the mouse brain. We implanted a glioblastoma brain tumor inside of the mouse brain and created a glass window overlying the brain, allowing us to image up to 2 mm inside of the brain. We labeled tumor-associated-macrophages, a type of cancer fighting cell, with LGNRs, and watched as single cells migrated in full 3d within the tumor. This is incredibly promising for monitoring the behavior of the cells over time, for example, as they react to immune-therapies, which stimulate the body’s innate defenses to fight against cancer. OCT is the only modality that can deliver the single-cellular resolution, wide imaging field of view, and deep penetration in tissue that makes such research possible.
